>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was very fat as a teenager. My cousin's kid was having a birthday party, and they were just chucking some stuff on the grill. Since there were a lot of people and they were all over the place, plates were placed out all around the house and the yard for people to grab food. Thus meant my parents couldn't really keep an eye on my consumption of food, like they usually do.

I downed 6 loaded hamburgers (as much cheese and bacon as patty), 5 bratwurst sandwiches, chips, a lot of soda, amd several slices of cake. Somehow I didn't actually feel too terrible in the moment, but just as we were leaving I started to feel queasy.

I had trouble falling asleep from the stomach ache. Eventually I did, but hours later (still in he dead of night) something inside me stirred violently and it awoke me. I had to rush naked to the bathroom and slammed my ass down on the toilet seat, where I proceeded to spew an ungodly amount of brown water from my asshole. This, combined with having consumed enough sodium earlier to have killed a horse, meant that as I sat there spewing forth a waterfall from my ass it felt like thick boiling poison was flowing through every one of my veins, a truly horrifying feeling. My stomach felt like someone was pumping it full of air to bursting point, and after that it happened.

Undigested chunks came flying out in an unholy cacophony. My body completely refused what I had crammed into it, and was just letting it all out. I spent HOURS on that toilet, not wanting to push because my asshole was incredibly sore and in tremendous pain, but needing to push because otherwise my stomach would act up and get stabbing pains. I unironically cried. After all the chunks had evacuated, I was left trying to push out a mostly clear, thick slime.

I washed my ass on the bidet (even the very gentle stream of water on my asshole stung by then) and I crawled back into bed teary eyed, feeling like what I can only asume violent anal rape by an elephant does, and passed out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I remember middle school health class covering the food pyramid and how even as a child it felt sketchy at best. It's turned upside its head in so many ways. Even going by its min serving recommendations results in ~2100 calories a day. 2s milk (488g, 293cal) + 2s beef steak (170g, 428cal) + 3s mixed veg (30oz, 546cal) + 2s mixed fruit (324g, 194cal) + 6s grain (174g, 660cal) = 2121cal.
It's a categorical simplification that prioritizes ease of sorting over nutritional impact. Consider the analogy: An exercise pyramid that categorizes exercises by dumbbell, barbell, machine, no weights / body weight, etc.. It's stupid.

The truest statement on food health is, and always has been, "Eat a well balanced diet in moderation."
What makes a diet balanced? Depends more on your body than anything else. Sometimes your body needs more of something or doesn't need as much of something. That need, or lack thereof, could be short-, medium-, or long-term.
If your body is low on an essential nutrient (protein, vitamin, acids, etc..) then eat more foods that contribute to that, preferably while keeping your avg caloric intake approximately constant.
If you want to lose weight you don't even have to change the balance of your diet. Just literally eat less of the same diet. Although, if your protein intake would drop too much I recommend altering the diet a bit to prevent that. That and regular exercise will help reducing your muscle loss as you lose weight.

Also for fucks sake, stop thinking of nutrition as something that has to be met every day. It's a rolling average over days, if not weeks. You don't need some crazy diet that has all of your essentials every day. Some days you get more of this and less or none of that. It's all about averages over time. If you really need breakpoints, use 3d and 7d averages.
When I wanted to lose weight I lost an avg of 2 lbs/wk over 4 months even though some days I had ~2500cal because I kept my avg daily intake under my target ~1500cal.

Each one is cooked best a different way, example, mushrooms need to be cooked on high heat because they're high moisture, brussel sprouts are good shredded and sauteed in bacon grease, cauliflower is a blank canvas for sauces and spices, salt your water like you would pasta before you before you boil green beans, roasted broccoli needs heavy oil and heavy salt and pepper, yellow onions are a good foundation for basically anything, etc etc. You want a variety in vegetables. Pick a vegetable, learn the best/most delicious way to cook it, then add it to your arsenal. Pretty soon you'll always have vegetable sides that are delicious and will make ur fat ass feel like you're doing something right for once in your life.

>>18745488
tangzhong is a way to get a nice softening effect on the bread and crust without having to buy any special ingredients.
if you are going to buy special ingredients, get some diastatic malt powder. its what they use in bagels to make the crust soft. and shiny.
adding sugar will also help with this, but the biggest contributor is fat. Kneading butter in to the dough is preferable to oil but oil will work. I've gone up to 500ml of olive oil for 2kilos of flour before, makes the bread insanely soft. To be honest, I prefer bread with a nice crispy crust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18745116
>starch gets more concentrated
This is the main advantage, yes. But it isn't so straight-forward. The main reason people are told to boil an absurd amount of water and then add pasta to it is that adding the pasta drops the temperature of the water somewhat, so by having sufficient water the temperature gets back to boiling very quickly, and the cooking rate of the pasta is very reliable.
You can put your pasta in cold water and then heat it up and cook it that way, which saves energy and water, but you have to work out the timing yourself so that you don't end up with a soggy exterior and an uncooked interior.
Still better than the absolute waste that is using tons of water to grow rice, then drying the grains, then washing them a ton, and then using more water to cook them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How to make the best frozen pizza thread
posts.com: Happy holidays! I've come to share my frozen pizza knowledge and enlighten anonymous land. To start, I prefer Red Baron, Newman's Own, and a couple others. I try to get the crust thin and crispy, as I want the crust to come out as crispy as possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: why does the chicken bag have “no antibiotics ever”, are americans afraid of antibiotics?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Heat the oven to 500 and put the frozen pizza in for approximately 5 minutes. It should come out looking like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now for the good stuff. I live in Michigan right next to a cloverleaf pizzeria. I buy their cups of pizza sauce and stock up. Add 1 cup of pizza sauce directly over the pizza.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now add the seasoning. I put a dash of rosemary, oregano, thyme, and plenty of crushed red pepper flakes for spice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Add the grilled chicken (I added a pinch of salt) and jalapeños.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I always make sure to get Whole milk mozzarella cheese. I add the cheese on top last. Put this back in the oven for 5 ~6 minutes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: And there you have it. A crispy crust, tons of sauce and cheese with flavor and spice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If anyone has other recommendations and tips, post 'em.

Put the chicken while still in the package into a bowl of water and let it sit.

It doesn't matter. As long as it's not frozen it's fine.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18739713
>why did it become such a meme?
It became a mild hipster thing because it was the default cheap table sauce at "alternative" Asian restaurants (Viet/Thai) in urban areas. Eventually marketers seized on it and suddenly "sriracha" was everywhere, just like "black angus beef" or the current ridiculous "wagyu" fetish. So naturally hipsters like you had to move on to something else. There's nothing amazing about sriracha. But there's nothing wrong with it either, it's just a relatively mild all-purpose chili sauce, thicker than Tabasco (so better for wings, etc), and a more interesting flavor than Frank's. Also Huy Fong Sriracha is an American company which should be worth something.

>its flavour is pretty fucking bland.
Name a popular sauce that isn't "bland" by your r/HotOnes standards, oh master of heat tolerance with a Collection of over 9,000 unopened sauces in your RGB-lit plexiglass display case.

>>18743724
>american

Unironically this. Obviously that doesn't mean that you can have a kaiseki breakfast every day, followed by some Chilean sea bass ceviche, Oysters on the half shell and langoustine with a fresh baked French baguette for lunch, and an assortment of obscure Taiwanese street food for dinner. But you can have all of those things to the extent that anyone else in the thread can have their idea of all those cuisines. I think most people just don't realize that food in the US is different. We don't think of it as "our food" vs "foreign food". It's more like, "do you feel like burgers or sushi or north indian or pizza [what kind?] or thai food or the pub with the really good whiskey bar or korean or greek or italian or tex-mex or the taqueria or the afghan place or the old school seafood house or..." Most other countries eat the same shit most of the time and then occasionally do "foreign food", but that's really not how it works in the States. Most people don't really see a difference between eating meatloaf sandwiches one night and kimchi jjigae the next, because it's all just food we have easily available.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18739526
>Will pressed purerh and white cakes continue to age after pressing
Yes they will, they are typically aged after pressing though they may age faster if loose.

>will they benefit from it?
Depends on if you prefer the aged taste or young taste. In general you should thing of the aged form as being different vs strictly being better. Fresh young sheng and well aged sheng are practically two different teas. Some really harsh or funky young puerh debatably are strait up better with aging though.

>leave them in the pantry now for a few years, will they benefit from it?
Fully aging tea takes a long time and is a slow processes in most conditions (e.g. semi aged sheng is 10ish years old, "fully" aged sheng is 20+ years old, white tea ages a bit faster). A few years in dry conditions will just make sheng a bit less green and "fresh", mellow out some of the bright floral notes of the white tea, and clear up some of the funk on shou or liu bao (probably the most useful scenario here for only aging 3 years). Starting out I would not buy tea solely to age but if you buy more tea than you drink there is nothing wrong with aging some of it. That's what I do at least.

>leave them in the pantry
Just be careful about the conditions there. You want the tea to be somewhere where it will not pick up smells. A lot of western puerh drinkers just store their tea in ziplock bags or sealed containers. The best way to store tea for aging in the west is a more complex topic and is still somewhat a mater of debate. Here are some blog posts that will put you in the right direction if you want to go down that rabbit whole.
https://teadb.org/low-barrier-puerh-storage-solutions-for-casual-puerh-drinkers/
https://teadb.org/simple-home-storage-solutions/
https://teadb.org/pumidors-101-designing-maintain-your-own-pumidor/
https://teadb.org/puerh-storage/

Anyone get anything preservation-related for Christmas? I got a new 3 liter ceramic crock, pic rel, and am going to share Anon's Basic Unspiced Kraut Recipe for anyone who ever wondered how to ferment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18743195
Kraut is a good way to start because it's easy and the principle translates to anything.
1. Prep the vegetable you're fermenting. for cabbage you do this by peeling off the outer leaves, keeping them as whole as possible and setting them aside, then halving and coring the cabbage and thin slicing.
2. Weigh your vegetables, then add about 5% of that weight in salt. Mix and let it sit about 20 minutes.
3. Bruise the vegetables by smashing. There are special tools for this, but you can do it by hand if you have to. You need them to release tons of water. Let them rest a few times while you're doing this.
4. Put it in your crock. The veg should have released enough water to just about cover. If they didnt, you can add tap water with 5% salt by weight.
5. Keep everything underwater. With cabbage, you put the outer leaves on top, then a weight on the outer leaves. They keep the sliced kraut underwater.
Anything above the brine will mold and provide an avenue for mold to penetrate the kraut below. So scoop any floaters.
6. Close the lid, keep the airlock watered, and check back in 2-4 weeks. Open it every few days to make sure there's no mold and scoop out any that forms, but otherwise keep it closed as much as possible.
Pic 1/4, removed outer leaves

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18743208
2/4, cabbage prepped and weighed. It's not important to be precise in slicing or weighing or even sanitation, sauerkraut is very forgiving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18743214
3/4 mashed. Note the liquid. I've added no water at this point, that's just cabbage juice and salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18743220
4/4 I hadn't really thought about how many cabbages to buy, I should have bought 2 more. This only filled my crock about halfway. That being the case, I needed to fill the crock with a considerable amount of 5% brine.
It's vital that all vegetable be covered in brine - it's good, but not vital, that there be as little headspace in your crock as possible. You also don't want to add too too much brine or you'll water down the final product.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18737181
There's only one commercially produced anymore and it's in this state. It is really strong and pungent, but the whole makes up for the sum of its parts. Everything has to be so over-the-top that they cancel each other out. Very rye bread (pumpernickel), very strong mustard, fresh red onions, and smoked spread liverwurst. Preferably with a dark beer.
Had a friend who fell asleep watching a movie while we were making it, and I gave it to him half passed out. While he was eating it he seemed fine, but then a piece fell out on his lap and he went to eat it. He immediately woke up and said what the fuck is? The individual ingredient is overpowering, but the ensemble kind of cancels each other out.

>>18742620
Yep, it's pork lau lau. It's fatty pork that's steamed with some fatty fish and salt wrapped in luau leaves (the leaves of the taro plant) and then wrapped in ti leaves (a Hawaiian plant). The closest thing to luau is spinach, but the flavor is really different, and then steaming it in the it leaves adds a whole other flavor. It's not really something you can describe if you haven't tried it, but in my mind those are some of the most Hawaiian flavors.
https://youtu.be/41Ho5vdZwNU

Ikizukuri, (roughly translated as "prepared alive" is the preparing of sashimi (raw fish) from live seafood. In this Japanese culinary technique, the most popular sea animal used is fish, but octopus, shrimp, and lobster may also be used.The practice is controversial owing to concerns about the animal's suffering, as it is still alive when served.

zaru soba: cold soba noodles
tan-tan ramen: sesame-based tonkotsu ramen that I still miss to this day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
okonomiyaki. i prefer hiroshima style over kansai style but it's up to you

any kind of katsu teishoku (set meal). tonkatsu is the most popular but they're all generally pretty good. also often comes in a curry variety (katsu-curry). if you're looking for crazy flavorful and spicy curry you're in the wrong country, japanese curry is really mild and more soupy but i like it a lot

takoyaki if you're in osaka, not really a "dish" though, more of a snack

unagi (eel)

tsukemen (cold dipping nooldes), amazing during warmer months and have a much more complex flavor profile than ramen IMO

any kind of tempura, i like shrimp and oyster but you can't go wrong with deep fried meat of any kind

umeshi (Japanese plum wine)

TV series is better and worth its own conclusion, and the movie is amazing and worth its own conclusion. I dont like the recap movies. But rebellion story is different. It's an all new soundtrack and its addictively good and completely underrated. I wish there was a falcom style remix of one for all in the soundtrack.

IT's impossible to talk about the content of the movie, but you probably heard things about its conclusion. I'll say that whatever your feelings on it, it doesn't feel warrented to say things are unsalvagably bad for fans of madoka. Madoka has constantly been someone who cares about homura and doesn't want her to suffer alone. I guess the best thing I can say about the movie if you have mixed feelings is it left things off between them in a state of equality. They have the capacity, if they chose, to have a serious conversation about their passive agressive struggle to martyr themselves for one another. But like Madoka 1-12 was a triumphant return of the powerful girl after cleansing herself of her own conciets, naiveties, and foolish ambitions, Rebellion story is about a counterattack to that. IT's literally the "strikes back" in japanese from star wars iirc. Homuras story and goal through the 12 episode anime was an abject failure. It needed to be so that madoka could shine brighter in the narrative. But are we really okay with madoka suffering the ultimate painful sacrifice if it means she gets to be free and strong? Is she? Is homura? Madoka the rebellion story is fundamentally the opposite of the narrative of 12, and the entire movie sets this up with a captivating worth watching on animation and painting grounds alone, toy like world. It's also amazing how, after dehuminizing and masculinizing herself in 12, homura recaptures her feminity in this film's theme

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This recipe has been passed down through my family for generations. I did not know that no one else had ever heard of it until my first high school girlfriend came home for dinner and it was served. She was hesitant at first but immediately love it the second she tasted it. I know you will too, and I am here to share it with the world.

Ingredients:

1 cup of dry brown lentils, rinsed and picked over
2 cups of water
1 bay leaf
1/2 teaspoon of salt
1 tablespoon of olive oil
1 medium onion, finely chopped
2 cloves of garlic, minced
1 medium carrot, diced
1 medium sweet potato, peeled and diced
1 cup of diced tomatoes
2 ripe bananas, sliced
1/2 cup of grated cheese (such as cheddar or mozzarella)
1/4 cup of chopped fresh herbs (such as parsley, cilantro, or basil)
Instructions:

Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.
In a medium saucepan, bring the lentils, water, bay leaf, and salt to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, for 20-25 minutes, or until the lentils are tender. Remove the bay leaf and drain any excess water.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook for 3-4 minutes, until the onion is translucent. Add the carrot and sweet potato and cook for an additional 5-7 minutes, until the vegetables are tender.
Stir in the cooked lentils, tomatoes, and sliced bananas. Spread the mixture evenly in the prepared baking dish.
Sprinkle the grated cheese over the top of the casserole.
Bake the casserole for 20-25 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and bubbly.
Garnish the casserole with the chopped fresh herbs and serve hot.

posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

I hate this "lifehack" with an undying fucking passion. I am convinced people doing this is 100% to blame for fast food restaurants never salting their fries appropriately any more. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I started making burgers at home I realised how little you actually need to make a good burger.
Lots of toppings just overcrowds a burger, makes it sloppy and unstable, you honestly just need 1 strongly flavoured topping.
My top is:
- jalapenos
- pickles (salt ones not vinegar)
- olives (green)
- NO KETCHUP, literally anything is better, I usually like weird shit like remoulade, but even mayo or a generic burger sauce is better than ketchup.
I don't even use cheese sometimes because i can't even taste it in the burger. Unless i use something strong. Irish cheddar actually worked well.
I should try to make the OG too, mustard, onions and meat. That's it. Should be tasty.

>>18744839
Stop repeating this nonsense. It's 2022, and the risk of getting sick from eating ground beef is virtually non-existent. Every restaurant cooks burgers to order, and medium-rare is by far the most popular way people order them. I'm not proud of the fact that I've cooked a thousand burgers, but it's part of the job when I'm working the grill, and I can assure you that when I have a $70 steak on the grill next to a $14 burger I'm going to cook both of them exactly how they were ordered. I went to McDonald's yesterday and got a Filet-O-Fish combo and a Bacon Clubhouse Burger. I was eating it in my vehicle in the parking lot and listening to an audio book when I glanced up and saw the McDonald's worker I ordered from was outside having a cigarette.

She waved at me and I nodded and had to wait 7 minutes before she went back inside and I could eat in comfort again. I don't think that employees should be bothering or even trying to socialize with customers outside of the McDonald's restaurant or drive through, but that is another story.

I went to McDonald's for dinner last night and got a Big Mac combo and a 10 piece Chicken McNuggets with barbecue dipping sauce. As I was driving to the second window the same girl was still working. She was acting somewhat obsequious and attempting small talk when she asked, 'why don't you come eat inside instead of in the parking lot'.

That really bothered me for many reasons. First of all, I don't want my routine or actions to be tracked by a fast food employee. Secondly, she should not try to tell me how I should live my life. I do not want to eat inside because I find it less comfortable and would much rather be inside my vehicle listening to an audiobook and enjoying myself and my privacy.

Overall, I think it was very unprofessional to bring this up. I should have a clean slate with each drive through visit, not have to get the third degree because I committed some sort of faux pas. Which I don't think I did, because I often see people eating in fast food parking lots. How does she know I am not busy going to work or somewhere in a rush?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I finally quit after 12 years of nicotine use and I feel completely fine. It was only hell for about a week, and then there were 2 more weeks of constantly thinking about nicotine and having to be sad that I couldn't have anymore. But now it's been a month and I'm completely over it, no more withdrawal symptoms, no more cravings, just feel 100% fine and normal. Except I don't need to keep consuming nicotine in order to be comfortable. I basically can just be comfortable indefinitely. It feels like there's a magical nicotine patch inserted inside my skin and it never runs out, so it just keeps feeding me pleasure and keeping me feeling content. I had no idea I could be like this. It's really awesome.

I always thought that if I quit, my life would basically be hell forever, since I'd always have to keep missing nicotine every day for the rest of my life. I thought it would be like having a wife tragically killed in a car accident and then you always miss her forever. I thought that even though the physical withdrawal could obviously go away, and chemically my brain would go back to normal, I'd never be able to forget the knowledge of how much I love smoking and dipping. I thought since I ate the forbidden fruit of knowledge, I was doomed to nicotine slavery forever.

I just can't express to you guys how fucking crazy it is that the feeling of missing cigarettes and feeling down and "lonely" about quitting, it literally just went away in under a month. I can't believe it was that fucking easy all along, and I just never stuck it out long enough to find this out sooner. I have been an addict for 12 fucking years and wishing I could stop for most of that time. And all along I literally could.

The shape doesn't matter to me. However I'll share my all time fave fry seasoning recipe sans specific measurements with y'all, for anyone curious. I eyeball the ingredients and just go by taste testing.

Salt (good amount)
Sugar (about 1/4 the amount of salt)
MSG (just a little bit)
Paprika
Cayenne
Onion powder
Garlic powder
Black pepper
Allium ash (I make at home by burning onion and garlic scraps and powdering the charred remains)

I swear this is a god tier seasoning when you strike the right balance.

>>18731754
>It's those billboards
There's an interesting story about that, actually.
As I understand it, back in 2000 there was legislation to try and limit the number of new billboards that could be built on the highways and interstates.
"New" being the operative word. Advertisers fought back by pre-emptively erecting a bunch of new billboards in hopes they'd get grandfathered in.

But after that, the bill failed and their would-be monopoly crumbled. There was a massive surplus with low demand, so advertising costs plummeted to pennies in the more rural areas of the state.

That's why you see cases where a church or a liquor store manages to buy 6 in a row. They're literally Bargain Bin Billboards.

Italian beef-Chad here. I've been to several portillos locations, as I've lived in Chicagoland throughout my entire life. Some locations have horrible staving issues and seem to be prone to getting orders incorrect. Other locations are more consistent.

Most reliable tier:
West loop
West Naperville
Oak Lawn
Schaumburg
Arlington heights

Unreliable tier:
River North
North Naperville
Bolingbrook
Niles
Summit
All the locations in Wisconsin and Indiana

Don't even bother because it's just a tourist trap/built for the sole purpose of extracting nostalgia dollars from gullible Chicagoans who fled Chicago tier:

All the locations in Arizona and California
Champaign

Just pick the right location and you can be reasonably certain that your food will come out correctly. It's sad that you gotta do this, but that's life. Despite all its issues, I still think portillos is the best chain Chicago cuisine restaurant. It's miles ahead of Al's and Buona, that's for sure.

Actually: ham is usually a scam. Most of the cheap ones aren't actually smoked. They are just injected with chemical slop to make it taste like smoke (for those who can taste it). Usually loaded with water weight to cut corners.

The fancier ones also tend to skimp on the smoking part as well, I always have to "double-smoke" the hams to make them taste properly smoked. This applies to the big ones as well as most deli cuts.

But, when properly smoked, ham is fantastic. Tender, flavorful, good browning on the crust. Simply fantastic. But you have to re-smoke the shit they sell you to fix it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hello friend, you've unknowingly committed one of the three cardinal Cane's sins, the other two of which are not substituting your slaw for extra sauce and not opening the styrofoam box when you get a to-go order to prevent sog: eating the tendies plain.

You see, Raising Cane's is a delicate, delectable balancing act of flavors, temperatures, and textures. Every item that comes with a meal is intended to be chained together. The tendie should ALWAYS be covered in some sauce, and you should ALWAYS follow up a bite with a french fry, a sip of your Arnold Palmer, some Texas toast, or a mix-and-match of the three. This gets you an immediate difference in sensation and flavor to compare against the scorching-hot chicken, tempered only by the cold, creamy sauce, much like pairing wine with cheese, to the betterment of both. There are many correct ways to enjoy the modern culinary jazz experience that is Cane’s, you’ve just so happened to pick the single incorrect one.

Make no mistake, Cane's tendies are consistently piping-hot, the fries are consistently salted, the sauce tastes the exact same way every time. The food comes out near instantly, the tea and lemonade are always fresh, and the employees will always give you the exact same amount of ice. Why, you might ask? Because to the seasoned eater, these are the perfect ratios of heat, of crunch, of quench for a melange that is as perfect as it is fairly priced, one that is limited only by your imagination and your understanding of all of my previous points.

I understand and sympathize with your error—many have made it in the past, and many will make it in the future. But surely the 30-car drive-thru, the rave reviews, the completely full parking lot, and the stalwart Cane’s customer loyalty are evidence of some larger disconnect between you and them beyond opinion.

Thanks for reading, and have a blessed day!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18737346
Nope. You would think so. It's heavily salted lamb meat, so you have to soak it in water for 24-36 hours and then you steam it for 3-5 hours until it's fork tender. You either put some wooden sticks or almond potatoes in the bottom of the pan for the steaming. It renders out an amazing fatty stock which you can use for sauce and if you do the potato version they will still be firm even though they have been boiled for 3-5 hours due to the salt and fat.

At the end you put them in the oven for 10 mins just to get a bit of color. The Rutabaga and carrot mash is sweet and creamy, balancing out the fatty, salty meat. On the side you have a shot of akevit to help against the fat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Polish fagg here, me and my family cooked pretty much the usual you see in Poland:
>Croquettes (2 types, one with sauerkraut and mushrooms, the other with eggs)
>Pierogies (sauerkraut with mushrooms and russian ones with potatoes and cottage cheese)
>Beetroot soup with "uszka" (these are basically mini pierogies with mushroom and sauerkraut filing that are boiled)
>Some kind of fish (don't remember which one it was, in the past it used to be carp because my grandfather really liked it)
>"Paszteciki", sauerkraut filled dough balls, baked in the oven with some nigella seeds on top. I have no clue why my mom calls them like this since they don't include any meat, but not gonna complain since they taste great
>leftover sauerkraut as a side
>bunch of spiced fries made from leftover potatoes
>Couple of cakes and cookies, most of them based around poppy seeds (most of them were too sweet for me, so I gave it a pass)

We also made bunch of food for us after Christmas Eve to eat with leftovers (some pork belly, ribs, chuck, salads, etc.). I really wanted to make some mulled wine or eggnog, but we didn't find much time, plus considering all the gifts and shit we kinda run out of budget. Overall had a great time.

Look for an end grain maple cutting board. Clean it with hot water and a clean sponge.
The big difference you will notice is the end grain dulls your knife edge less than bamboo. And has a noticable feel when sliced into unlike Teflon.
Rumor/olde wives tale is that the tannins in the wood prevent bad bacteria from growing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18743448
City ham is a term used in some parts of the United States for any lightly cured and/or smoked ham which must be refrigerated to preserve it. It is generally "wet cured", that is injected with or soaked in a brine solution containing high concentrations of salts (including sodium chloride, sodium nitrate, and sodium nitrite). This is distinguished from country hams which are dry cured by being packed in crystalline curing salts and stored at room temperature. In parts of the U.S. where country ham is not consumed, city hams are often the only available hams and are just called ham.

posts.com: I have no idea, I'm a vegetarian and when I occasionally do have meat, it has to be kosher.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18744435
does freezing meat actually change the taste/texture of it once it's thawed?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18744481
Yes, unless it's flash frozen. Normal freezing will create larger ice crystals inside the meat that break apart the muscle fibers causing it to lose more moisture when thawed, and can give a grainy texture. Flash freezing avoids this by simply freezing the meat so quickly that the ice crystals don't have time to grow as large.

freezing steaks will deteriorate them, and freezing delicate seafood like scallops will ruin the texture, but freezing stuff like ground beef, chicken that's going to get fried, any meat thats going to be braised etc you'd be hard pressed to tell the difference. Kitchen Nightmares created this perception that freezers are only for lazy chefs, but freezing food saves the restaurant thousands of dollars, and they always have way worse problems. In my opinion, frozen vegetables are way more noticable than a burger made with frozen mince, or fried-from-frozen chicken. Freezing fries usually results in a better product.

posts.com: For me - who's rarely lived any more than 5 miles from an abattoir and the freshest high grade meat (in my later life) I actually agree with GR on this. Let me explain - meat in the US is OK. Unless you hunt out really high quality (mostly shipped in because of distance). Now I live in England and my local supermarket has beef, chicken, lamb etc shipped fresh from local farms. Never frozen. Even if I want Scottish (Aberdeen Angus) beef it has never been frozen. It is just maybe 3 hours refrigerated drive away and it genuinely tastes better. Of course I love my old country but until you have experienced what is out in the rest of the world fresh you will never know. GR is just a bong who's eaten fresh bong meat and knows the difference.

They literally have the best brussels sprouts somehow. They are are roasted and crispy, have a soy ginger glaze, with crispy fried onions and bacon crumbled on top. There's a lot of copycat recipes for it. I've never had brussels sprouts better in my entire life. The Ultimate Feast used to be a favorite of mine but the portions are smaller and it's like the double the price. The lobster bisque is also very high quality, which the biscuits are a nice complement with it.

posts.com: Hi all, I got a food dehydrator for my birthday a few months ago. I have made several batches that taste good, but they never have the consistency and mouth feel of store bought jerky. So I am asking what I'm doing wrong? My process is to take the meat, let it sit in a marinade for 4-12 hours, then dehydrate for 8-12 hours. The meat usually tastes good, but it's way more tough than store bought. Is there a step or a chemical component I'm missing? Pic related it's beef jerky on top of some spam I tried to jerky based off a YouTube video. (The Spam jerky wasn't bad.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742116
Youll probably never get the consistency of commercial jerky but pineapple juice in the marinade and marinating for way longer will help
I usually do about a week

posts.name: Failmcweaksaws
posts.com:
>>18742148
Just so I understand, you marinade for an entire week? I can understand how that can break down the protein and make it more tender but don't you run the risk of it going bad?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742116
After you cut the strips, mix them with some bicarbonate of soda for ten to fifteen minutes, rinse well, then marinade. The bicarbonate sets the protein. You don’t need quite as much time in the dehydrator as the meat is effectively already ‘cured’ chemically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Let it marinate longer. Marinate in soy sauce 24 hours or at least overnight. Add a few more hours to your dehydration (maybe at a lower temp). I like to sprinkle a little red and black pepper on mine. Also cheap cuts like london broil are the best 4 jerky. Good luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742116
>>18743669
this
thinly cut London broil marinate a minimum of 24 hours..again, minimum

posts.name: Failmcweaksaws
posts.com: OP here, thanks for the tips. I will try the bicarbonate of soda thing and marinate longer. I'll also try London broil as the cut.

posts.com: Lets cook burgers for breakfast. First pre heat your frying pan. Its important that the non stick surface on your frying pan is worn down so the burgers get a nice mallard action. Take a pound of finest 3 day old ground beef and form into half pound patties and add to your pre heated frying pan

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18742570
nice meatballs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742570

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742575
Too much seasoning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742575
When you flip your burgers they should look like this. That crust from the mallard action is where the optimum flavor is at.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742577
Next we put a spare pan over the burgers for two reasons. We want to not get grease all over the stove, and more importantly we want to ensure the burgers are cooked fully through, with no pink left. Pink indicates a chance you're going to get ill from food poisoning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18742579
While your patties are cooking on the 2nd side, its time to slice up some read onion. Red onion is best for burgers, but if you have a white onion you can use that in a pinch too. But never use nasty yellow onions.

posts.com:
>>18742580
Next we add the best store brand American cheese for the melty flavor.

posts.com:
If a meal is truly superb, I will often request to speak to the chef. Usually, it's no problem and they are appreciative that their craft and labour has been enjoyed.

However, there was one experience that left me rather shaken and made me consider if I should ever do it again. I travel most days of the week for work. We set up alot of IT stuff for hospitals. One day I was travelling to somewhere in Kentucky. I was excited to go because 1.) I had never been and 2.) I was excited to try the local fare and learn more about what people ate there. We got in late and really didn't have time to eat anywhere particularly locale the first night, but after arriving to work the next day we were recommended to eat at a place called "Randy's Kountry Kitchen". I was a little hesitant because the name sounded foreboding, but I trusted our advice and we headed out for lunch.

I normally eat alone as I tend to take my time, but this time I rode along with some new coworkers. We were seated in a what appeared to be a very rundown shack. There were flies everywhere and our checkered tablecloth was sticky. The waitress was very rude and just asked "What y'all want?" I didn't have time to peruse the menu, which just happened to be a piece of printer paper listing their items so I informed her I would need a few minutes. My coworkers immediately started drinking. They just got burgers. I thought that was foolish and opted to get their special: A chicken fried steak with pepper gravy. I was floored. It was fried just right and the gravy was smooth and creamy. My coworkers at this point were beginning to get more and more inebriated, even though it was a lunch break and I began to wonder how we were going to get back. As, I stated I usually take my time with my food. My coworkers began to tease and berate my eating habits. One said "I ate like a faggot" to which I found very insulting. I wanted to savor every bite and took my time. Anyways onto "my compliments

After 45 minutes I finished my meal and asked our crude waitress if I could speak to the chef. My coworkers groaned and one even dared to throw a fork at at me. I think that it someone really does something great they should know about it. Our waitress seemed confused, but went back to the kitchen anyways. While doing this, my coworkers left to use the bathroom. Several minutes later a morbidly obese man wearing a very dirty motorhead shirt lumbered over to my table and introduced himself as Randy. He asked me "what was wrong with my food". I informed him that I wished to tell him the latter and that I found his meal to be delicious. The man seemed perplexed and just stared at me. I took of my cap, (I was wearing a baseball hat at the time) and tipped in his direction in a respectful manner as to say thank you. He immediately became furious. He asked if "I was coming on to him" and said that "He doesn't allow any fucking queers in his Kountry Kitchen". I didn't even get a chance to pay and was chased out of the restaurant rapidly.

To my shock my coworkers had not gone to the bathroom but had snuck out and left me at Randy's Kountry Kitchen and I had to walk 2 miles to the nearest gas station to call a cab back to work.

Have you ever given "your compliments?"
